Brady Geothermal Power Plant Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary (revision 1, April 13, 2018)



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is Brady Power Partner's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. The Brady

Geothermal facility actively manages all operational permits and safety programs such as Nevada

Department of Environmental Protection Air Quality, Chemical Accident Prevention Program,

Underground Injection Control as well as OSHA's Process Safety Management. Ormat is committed to handling the flammable motive fluid systems in a safe manner to protect the environment. Copies of emergency response, process hazard analyses and all other process safety management is maintained onsite for reference or is available electronically.



Facility Description

The Brady Geothermal Power Plant is wholly owned by Brady Power Partners. The Brady

Geothermal facility is located in Churchill County. The physical plant is located at 7042 Old Highway

40, east of Fernley, Nevada. The leased acreage covers the defined geothermal resource area and reinjection zones.



Prior to March, 2018, the Brady facility consisted of three, steam-powered turbines and one OEC (Ormat Energy Converter), aka existing OEC.  Since then, Ormat has added one new OEC and just recently completed the revamp of the existing OEC.  The new OEC process is named OEC-1 and the existing OEC process is named OEC-2.  The three, steam-powered turbines are being decommissioned.



This RMP submission reflects the new process, OEC-1 and the revamped process, OEC-2. 



Under the current configuration, Brady is supplied hot geothermal brine from six, pumped production wells.  OEC-1 and OEC-2 both process the brine through a closed loop, binary Rankine Cycle.  The hot brine circulates through the tube side of shell and tube heat exchangers to preheat and vaporize the motive fluid on the shell side.  In the binary Rankine Cycle, the normal butane (motive

fluid for OEC-1) and iso-pentane (motive fluid for OEC-2) exits the shell side of the heat exchangers at high pressure, expands across a turbine to drive a generator (13.2 MW for OEC-1 and 5.2 MW for OEC-2), is condensed in air cooled condensers, and is recirculated to the heat exchangers via vertical turbine pumps.  Geothermal brine exiting the OECs is re-injected, via re-injection pumps, into a different part of the geothermal reservoir in six wells.  



The Brady Power Plant is operated by Ormat's Western Nevada Operations Group. The WNV Operations

Group (WNVOPS) is comprised of management, administration, maintenance, engineering and operations personnel.  WNVOPS operates the Western Nevada power generation facilities owned or operated by Ormat.



Brady is a remotely operated facility.  Remote operations are conducted out of the Galena 3 control room located in Reno, NV.  On-site staff will typically consist of one plant operator, two maintenance personnel and two electrical personnel which are shared between another local facility and the

Brady facility.  Additional operational, maintenance, management and administrative support is provided to the Brady facility from the Steamboat Complex located in Reno, NV.  The Brady facility operates continuously 24 hours a day and 365 days of the year (excluding scheduled maintenance downtime or plant upsets).



 

Regulated Substance Handled:  The Brady Geothermal Power Plant utilizes normal butane in OEC-1 and iso-pentane in OEC-2 as its motive fluid.  Each OEC contains in excess of the 10,000 pound threshold quantity.  



Worst Case Scenario: Worst case scenario assessment has been made and potential off-site consequence analysis (OCA) was conducted.  Any potential offsite receptors were identified.



Safe Work Practices: Safe work practices have been developed and implemented to provide for the control of hazards during work activities such as lock out/tag-out, confined space entry, opening process equipm

ent or piping, and control over entrance into a facility by maintenance, contractor, laboratory or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply to both employees and contractors.



Maintenance Procedures: A Mechanical Integrity Program (MIP) has been developed for the Brady facility. The MIP adopts a maintenance concept for periodic preventative and corrective maintenance of the OEC system. The preventative maintenance tasks include visual inspection, lubrication of rotating parts, system cleaning, replacing liquids and filters, and periodic tests to verify that the system is in proper operating condition. Preventative maintenance tasks and procedures are scheduled to be undertaken over a series of maintenance intervals. The Mechanical Integrity Program identifies system maintenance procedures, frequencies and recommended spare parts, manufacturer's recommendations, operating experience and best practices.



Alarm system maintenance is determined using a combination of regulatory requirements, manufacturer's recommendations, plant operating experience and best practices.



Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOPs give detailed safe operating instructions on Normal Operations, Plant Startup and Shutdown and Emergency Operations. Additionally covered are operations of Fire Protection and Gas Detection System, Electrical Distribution System, Butane and Pentane Systems, Brine System, Evacuation, Transfer, and Storage System, Non-Condensable Gas Removal System, Turbine Controls and Support Systems, Compressed Air System and Cooling Water System.



Training: Initial training for personnel is given before an employee is allowed to operate or work on the facility's process area or on process equipment. Training Qualifications for both operation personnel and maintenance personnel are required and renewed periodically to validate knowledge and understanding of expected work performance. Refresher training of safety programs are conducted on an annual basis

for all affected personnel, at a minimum, and when review of the chemicals or processes reveals a need for additional training.

Initial and refresher training is documented and maintained per the requirements of the Training Program.

Contracted employees, shall be trained in the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan procedure prior to working at the Brady site. Training includes the following items, but is not limited to: (a) Location and sounds of the gas, fire, and evacuation alarms and detectors; (b) Expectations of response to injuries and emergencies by personnel on site, and (c) Evacuation routes and locations.

Refresher training for all personnel shall be conducted annually at a minimum.

Safety Training: Some equipment at the Brady Power Plant poses potential fire, explosion, and electrical hazards that could cause serious personal injuries and costly property damage if safety procedures are not followed correctly. Safety training, conducted monthly and required of all employees, identifies the different hazards to be found on the sites. These subjects include Emergency Action Plan (EAP), motive fluid hazards, fire prevention and hot work, lock out and tag out procedures, hazard communication, confined space, hearing conservation, personal protective equipment, accident, injury and incident reporting. Safety training is supplemented by the use of the Standard Safety Procedures.



OEC Units: The OEC units are controlled and monitored by their own dedicated Programmable

Logic Controller (PLC). The PLC receives all discrete (logic) and analog signals from the input devices (e.g. switches and measuring sensors), processes the signals according to pre-loaded Ormat software, and then outputs logic and analog command signals to local and field devices. All parameters needed for proper operation of the OEC units, such as pressure, temperature, voltage, current, power, speed, etc. are measured by the proper measuring instruments. Deviation from the operating

parameters will immediately be detected by the PLC and the PLC will initiate correction, Alarms or automatic shutdown of the related OEC unit. Under normal circumstances, no releases or other dangerous situations are expected to result from these automatic actions. 



Relief system design: Relief valves are located on the storage tank, OEC vaporizers and condensers. Each pressure relief valve relieves directly to atmosphere, and some installations have extension pipes installed to direct the relief valve discharge away from critical machinery. Additionally, each pressure relief valve is installed immediately above a rupture disk designed to fail at the relief pressure of its corresponding relief valve. Individual relief valve locations are equipped with "telltale" gauges in between the relief valve and its rupture disk to allow easy identification of leaking or blown rupture disks.



Ventilation System Design: All components of the motive fluid transfer and storage system and the

OEC unit are located outdoors and well ventilated.



Safety Systems: Beyond the relief system the Brady OEC units have extensive fire protection, detection, and alarming systems as well as an administrative control system aimed at fire prevention.

The fire detection systems include gas monitors which continuously monitor the area surrounding the OEC's, and multi-spectrum infrared flame detectors throughout the plant. The facility has a fire water loop around the plant within reach of the OECs and storage tanks. The fire water loops consist of fire pumps, water tanks, monitors, hydrants and a deluge system for the iso-pentane storage tank.  The butane storage tank is coated with a fireproofing insulation that prevents tank shell from overheating for up to two hours without fire water application to help prevent a tank boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion.  Operators are trained in the proper use of the installed fire protection equipment, and the training information is appropriate

ly documented by the facility operator.  



Process Hazard Analysis

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) including Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study, an external events analysis and a preliminary human factors analysis was revalidated in September, 2016. The recommendations of the PHA were integrated into the facility and facility operations. The PHA will be updated and revalidated at least every 5 years to ensure the study is consistent for the life of the OEC processes.



Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of normal butane or iso-pentane.  



Emergency Response Program:  The Emergency Action Plan is intended to identify and coordinate personnel in the event there is an emergency. The EAP procedures apply to all personnel working at the Brady Geothermal facility.  The EAP is submitted to the local fire department for review and approval and when changes are made to the plan. The following information was selectively excerpted from the Brady Geothermal Emergency Action Plan (EAP).



Motive Fluid Leak or Fire Emergencies: An emergency is identified as any type of fire, explosion, or motive fluid spill (ruptured vessel, process pipe, etc.) within the plant. Under no circumstances is any person to put himself/herself in danger. A General Response and Action Chart has been prepared to provide guidance on the initial response and follow up actions in the event of a motive fluid vapor, smoke or fire detection alarm.



Implementation, Control and Compliance: The Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Emergency Action Plan. The Emergency Action Plan shall be reviewed annually to verify regulatory compliance and accuracy with both OSHA Regulations on

Emergency Plans 29, CFR 1910.38 and NDEP-CAPP's Emergency Response Programs, NAC

459.9544. The Emergency Response Program must also be periodically reviewed and updated and employees notified of any changes in conformance with 40 CFR 68.95. The

EAP may also be reviewed, as part of any Incident Investigations or when deemed required during Management of Change. Current copies of the Emergency Action Plan are located in the Brady Geothermal Control

Room.

Evacuation of Personnel: In the event of an emergency determined to be motive fluid system-related and evacuation is deemed necessary, the control room operator or other designated personnel will sound the plant evacuation alarm if not automatically initiated by gas or flame detectors.



First Aid: All personnel have been trained in adult CPR and basic first aid procedures.



Control Room Operator: Upon notification from the site that an emergency has occurred, the Control

Room Operator shall verify an emergency shutdown of the plant was initiated and emergency response teams have been called. The Control Room Operator assumes initial communications with site over emergency situations until relieved by either the Plant Manager or Operations Manager.



Emergency Response Personnel: Fire, police, and/or ambulance crews will be called as necessary.

The senior employee on site at the time of the incident will give a report to the person in charge of the emergency teams. This report will include currently known causes and effects, reports of injured personnel and their locations, etc. All other employees are instructed to stay clear unless specifically requested to assist in some manner.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety: The plant has been operating safely for many years and Ormat will continue to ensure extensive training is provided to the operators as they are essential to plant safety. In addition to implementation of recommendations generated by the PHA, Ormat will continue to evaluate any new mitigation or control technology that may improve safety at the Brady Geothermal Power Plant.
